qas.question: What is also a major note in Ciudad Vieja?
What is the burial place of Fructuoso Rivera?
Where is the equestrian statue of Bruno Mauricio de Zabala located?

context: Also of major note in Ciudad Vieja is the <a0_0>Plaza de la Constitución<a0_0/> (or Plaza Matriz). During the first decades of Uruguayan independence this square was the main hub of city life. On the square are the Cabildo—<a1_0>the seat of colonial government<a1_0/>—and the <a2_0>Montevideo Metropolitan Cathedral<a2_0/>. The cathedral is the burial place of Fructuoso Rivera, Juan Antonio Lavalleja and Venancio Flores. Another notable square is <a3_0>Plaza Zabala<a3_0/> with the equestrian statue of Bruno Mauricio de Zabala. On its south side, Palacio Taranco, once residence of the Ortiz Taranco brothers, is now the Museum of Decorative Arts. A few blocks northwest of Plaza Zabala is the Mercado del Puerto, another major tourist destination.
